articles.headline: Staying Private on the New Facebook
articles.snippet: How to guard your information on Facebook in light of the new search tool that lets strangers discover who you are, what you like and where you go.
articles.abstract: How to guard your information on Facebook in light of the new search tool that lets strangers discover who you are, what you like and where you go.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook is a personal vault that can contain photos of your firstborn, plans to bring down your government and, occasionally, a record of your indiscretions.

articles.headline: Two-Tax Rise Tests Wealthy in California
articles.snippet: California’s top earners are now facing a combined 51.9 percent federal and state income tax — the highest rate in the nation — a cause for grumbling and, maybe, an incentive to move.
articles.abstract: California’s top earners are now facing a combined 51.9 percent federal and state income tax — the highest rate in the nation — a cause for grumbling and, maybe, an incentive to move.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — It is getting awfully expensive to be a millionaire in California.

articles.headline: Crew-Only 787 Flight Is Approved by F.A.A.
articles.snippet: Federal regulators approved one flight of a Boeing 787, with a crew but no passengers, as engineers study ways to reduce the risks of another battery fire.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators approved one flight of a Boeing 787, with a crew but no passengers, as engineers study ways to reduce the risks of another battery fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators said on Wednesday that they had approved one flight of a Boeing 787, with a flight crew but no passengers, as the company’s engineers study possible changes to the plane’s electrical systems that could reduce the risk of another battery fire.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
articles.snippet: The White House’s order to release classified documents came on the eve of the Senate hearing for John O. Brennan, President Obama’s choice to be C.I.A. director.
articles.abstract: The White House’s order to release classified documents came on the eve of the Senate hearing for John O. Brennan, President Obama’s choice to be C.I.A. director.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Wednesday directed the Justice Department to release to the two Congressional Intelligence Committees classified documents discussing the legal justification for killing, by drone strikes and other means, American citizens abroad who are considered terrorists.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Lighter Menus Appeal to Diners and Owners
articles.snippet: Pressured by looming regulations, restaurants across the United States are shrinking portion sizes, a move that is paying off financially.
articles.abstract: Pressured by looming regulations, restaurants across the United States are shrinking portion sizes, a move that is paying off financially.
articles.lead_paragraph: Driven by pressures like consumer demand and looming federal regulations that will require them to post calorie counts on menus, restaurant chains around the country are adding more nutritious choices and shrinking portion sizes.

articles.headline: Pakistani Militant, Price on Head, Lives in Open
articles.snippet: The United States has offered $10 million for help convicting Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, the Pakistani founder of the group behind the 2008 attacks in Mumbai, India.
articles.abstract: The United States has offered $10 million for help convicting Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, the Pakistani founder of the group behind the 2008 attacks in Mumbai, India.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — Ten million dollars does not seem to buy much in this bustling Pakistani city. That is the sum the United States is offering for help in convicting Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, perhaps the country’s best-known jihadi leader. Yet Mr. Saeed lives an open, and apparently fearless, life in a middle-class neighborhood here.

articles.headline: E-Mails Imply JPMorgan Knew Some Mortgage Deals Were Bad
articles.snippet: E-mails and employee interviews filed as part of a lawsuit show that JPMorgan Chase flouted quality controls as it bundled mortgages into complex financial instruments.
articles.abstract: E-mails and employee interviews filed as part of a lawsuit show that JPMorgan Chase flouted quality controls as it bundled mortgages into complex financial instruments.
articles.lead_paragraph: When an outside analysis uncovered serious flaws with thousands of home loans, JPMorgan Chase executives found an easy fix.

articles.headline: U.S. Increases Pressure of Economic War on Tehran
articles.snippet: The United States blacklisted several organizations in Iran on Wednesday, widening the American effort to pressure the government over its nuclear program and human rights abuses.
articles.abstract: The United States blacklisted several organizations in Iran on Wednesday, widening the American effort to pressure the government over its nuclear program and human rights abuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — All over this city of 12 million people, high-rises are under construction, local engineers and Chinese contractors are rushing to finish a multilevel highway, and the streets are lined with billboards promoting the latest tablets and washing machines made by South Korean companies like Samsung and LG. Supermarkets are fully stocked, and it seems as if new restaurants and fast food joints are opening up every day, and never lacking for customers.
articles.byline: By Thomas Erdbrink and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: 4 Years After Crisis, Ireland Strikes Deal to Ease a Huge Debt Load
articles.snippet: The Irish government reached a deal on Thursday with the European Central Bank to restructure debt tied to local struggling banks.
articles.abstract: The Irish government reached a deal on Thursday with the European Central Bank to restructure debt tied to local struggling banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Irish government, trying to lighten the staggering debt burden of bailing out some of its biggest banks four years ago, reached a deal on Thursday with the European Central Bank to give the country more time to repay some of those loans.

articles.headline: Einhorn Sues Apple Over Plan to Discard Preferred Stock
articles.snippet: David Einhorn sued Apple to block a plan to eliminate preferred shares, showing deep dissatisfaction with the company’s once-explosive stock.
articles.abstract: David Einhorn sued Apple to block a plan to eliminate preferred shares, showing deep dissatisfaction with the company’s once-explosive stock.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Drones Are Focus as C.I.A. Nominee Goes Before Senators
articles.snippet: Members of the Senate Intelligence Committee pressed John O. Brennan, the nominee for director of the Central Intelligence Agency, on the secrecy of targeted killings and their legal basis.
articles.abstract: Members of the Senate Intelligence Committee pressed John O. Brennan, the nominee for director of the Central Intelligence Agency, on the secrecy of targeted killings and their legal basis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Engaging a high-ranking Obama administration official for the first time in an extensive public discussion of the use of drones for targeted killing, members of the Senate Intelligence Committee on Thursday pressed John O. Brennan, President Obama’s nominee for director of the Central Intelligence Agency, about the secrecy of the strikes, their legal basis and the reported backlash they have produced in Pakistan and Yemen.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Scott Shane
